MDSC701
Notes
Introduction to Research Methods is a 15 credit module that can be taken as part of a programme of study, or as a stand-alone introduction for students with little or no background in Research Methods. This module is a revised version of the 20 Credit "Research Methods Online" and is suitable for all health care professionals and social scientists.

The staff involved in teaching this module will span the Faculty, allowing expertise to be drawn from the specialist academic areas from the programmes of study in which the module sits. This will allow influence of context and relevance of specialist research methods knowledge.

Overview

Overview
This introductory module provides an opportunity to students to develop understanding of the research process, from the theoretical stances that support empirical enquiry, to the publication of the evidence.

This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Students will need to opt into one of the delivery patterns prior to starting the module.

The module is structured with seven weeks teaching activity using e-lectures and small group work. The staff will deliver the e-lectures in a way that promotes active learning, by using a “sliced” approach where activities (questions, critical reflection) punctuate the presentation. Materials covered within e-lectures are consolidated through small group work, where students will work in dedicated learning sets to address topics for wider discussion amongst the larger group.

The summative assessment will employ the critical skills developed over the course of the module, through the structured critique of a student selected research paper, and the analysis of a provided data set. This assessment strategy will ensure that students have the opportunity to demonstrate key skills within the research process, and provides students with the opportunity to focus on areas of interest specific to their academic/clinical practice.

The module content will be taught by a range of experts from across the Health and Life Science Faculty. Its format has been designed to widen national and international participation, to increase numbers and viability.
Educational Aims
The aims and subsequent learning outcomes have been developed using a knowledge, clinical/research skills, learner development and professional behaviour format, commensurate with the philosophical hallmarks outlined in the University of Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Commensurate with Masters/Level 7 study, this module will:
•Facilitate the development of basic knowledge and core skills in qualitative and quantitative research;
•Enable students to develop a critical awareness of the processes required for successful planning and delivery of research;
•Equip students with appropriate and transferable communication skills for the development of research processes and reporting of analysis.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will facilitate students to develop a critical understanding and ability to appraise the design, development, process and analysis of research within health and social science. The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework hallmarks engaging: Research Connected Teaching; Active Learning, and Authentic Assessment. Further, the curriculum will provide students with the opportunity to develop: Confidence - in their skills and knowledge of research methods; Digital fluency - through engaging digital platforms for academic development and educational activities; and Global Citizenship - through encountering and appreciating international approaches and perspectives on the collection and analysis of data.

The module is aimed at those who have little experience in research and are looking to prepare for a masters level research project. At the end of this module, students will be able to understand and appropriately critique the elements of 'the research journey' from the conception of an idea, through development/approval, execution, analysis and reporting.

The syllabus for this module is aligned with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework and demonstrates active learning and authentic assessment, designed to develop confidence and understanding of research evidence, and how this influences their own area of practice.

The module will have a flexible approach, and will be delivered; online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Delivery will be supported by lectures, audiovisual presentations, quizzes and case-based interactive discussion boards and tutorials.

There are two assessments within this module, aligned to the development of core research skills:
1. Critique of a Research Article: 2,000 words
2. Data Analysis Activity: Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis Exercise: Poster Presentation.

The assessments can be tailored to focus on the student's area of interest and area of speciality.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus for this module is aligned to the hallmarks of the University of Liverpool Curriculum Framework. The syllabus is structured to ensure that current research and thinking supports the development of a critical understanding of research methods; that students are active learners and engage with the material and teaching team to direct their learning and participate in assessments that are contextualised for their professional development.

The syllabus incorporates the following key areas:

-Theoretical underpinnings of research enquiry: Ontology, Epistemology, Paradigms and Research Methods.

-Principles of critical appraisal: Research Design & Methodologies; Evaluation Tools (EQUATOR Network; CASP); Reliability; Validity; Bias; Analysis and Reporting.

-Structured approaches to literature review: Principles of Review; Review Formats (Systematic, Scoping, Narrative); Structuring Reviews (PRISMA; PRISMA-ScR; SWiM; SANRA).

-Introduction to qualitative research and data analysis: Research Problems and Qualitative Methods; Study Design; Sampling; Data Collection Techniques; Introducing approaches to data analysis (Thematic Analysis; Grounded Theory; Integrated Phenomenological Analysis).

-Introduction to quantitative research and data analysis: Research Problems and Quantitative Methods; Study Design; Sampling frameworks; Data Collection Techniques; Understanding Data; Introducing approaches to descriptive and inferential analysis.

-Research ethics: History of Ethics in Health and Social Science Research; Core Principles of Research Ethics; Regulatory Frameworks for Approval.

-Writing for research publication: Principles of Academic Writing; Writing a Research Paper.

The syllabus is actioned through the release of weekly online lectures, addressing the core content and learning objectives of theme for the week.

Lectures: are presented in a "sliced" format - where questions /reflection points are integrated, and students are required to address the activities outlined. For example, during a lecture students may be asked to identify the strengths and limitations of an 'evidence based approach' to practice - pause the lecture whilst they note their thoughts (and findings from internet searches) - and contract their thoughts with those subsequently presented in the lecture.

Group Work: The learning points addressed in the Lectures will form part of the core activity within the online group learning (Learning Sets n=6-8) following the online lecture. Here, students will reflect on identified reading, linked videos and prompted questions relating to the weekly theme. Students will post thoughts, reflections and findings on a discussion board within the VLE, which is supported/moderated daily by the teaching staff. A weekly rotating student chair will be appointed to drive the discussion and report back from the group, to the wider class.

Tutorials: Students are able to access tutorial support in relation to the module content. Equally, learning sets can set up a group tutorial as required/needed to discuss core content.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. The module uses a blend of video lectures, asynchronous discussion boards, and tutorials to progressively build students understanding of a range of research knowledge and practical skills for research.

Sliced Lectures
Topics within the syllabus are introduced with weekly pre-recorded sliced lectures (where questions are asked within the lecture presentation and students are asked to reflect and address points within the presentation). (14 Hours)

Learning Sets
Following the weekly Lecture, the use of tutorials or discussion boards is used to post questions to reflect and engage with. Students will be split into active learning sets (minimum 6, maximum 8) to engage with the discussion question. This activity can take place asynchronously or synchronously according to the demands/opportunities within the learning set (this approach ensures active learning and participation in either an on-line or face to face environment; it also addresses connectedness and personal responsibility for learning). For all students, one member from the learning set (on a rotational basis) will post the findings on a module-wide discussion board, where students can further review, analyse and provide constructive critical comment. (35 Hours)

Supervision
To enable student to structure and focus their learning and structure appropriate assessments, 1-1 supervision is provided. (1.5 hours). Group supervision sessions will complement the above (2.5 hours).

Self-Directed Learning
Students will be required to access directed and supplementary material on a week-by-week basis, aligned to the subject being addressed each week. This information will be presented within the VLE, such as directed/suggested reading material to support the online lecture material and/or group learning activities. The students will also direct their learning to further material pertinent to their particular area of interest (academic/professional) in order to support assessment activities. (97 Hours)

The curriculum for this module is aligned to the hallmarks of the University of Liverpool Curriculum framework:

Research Connected Teaching
The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of basic and clinical sciences with research. The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms.

Authentic Assessment
Within assessment 2, examples of real/published data sets will be used on which students can review and apply the learning engaged through the module. addition, students (in discussion with the Module Team) will select a current research paper within their own field of interest to critically review.

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to analyse data and critique papers effectively, informing their knowledge base and application to research practice.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the student's professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Masters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their developing proficiency in two key elements of understanding and applying research processes: critical review of research; applied analysis and reporting on research data. These assessments will establish a foundation for students who then wish to advance further and develop a research protocol (MDSC702 Advanced Research Methods: Design and Data Analysis).

1.Critical Review c. 2000 words
Students must produce a critical review of a research paper (pre-approved / student's own choice) and will provide an in-depth appraisal critiquing the supporting literature review, research methods, analysis of results and reporting of the findings.

2. Data Analysis Task - Poster Presentation
Students will be required to examine and analyse a set of qualitative and quantitative data, then create and present a poster highlighting the findings from their analysis.

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module. For Assessment 1, students will need to familiarise themselves with critical approaches to review research papers (e.g. GREENHALGH, T. How to read a paper - 5th ed ISBN 9781118801116) apply tools that support critical review (such as CASP https://casp-uk.net/) and required reporting guidelines (https://www.equator-network.org/). For Assessment 2, students will need to engage with, practice and apply analysis techniques identified within the module learning opportunities provided.

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Reviewing research evidence, and preparing research data for presentation and publication are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of authentic assessment.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 To articulate and critically appraise theory underpinning a range of qualitative and quantitative approaches to research enquiry.
 M2 To critically appraise and apply quantitative approaches to data collection, analysis and reporting.
 M3 To critically appraise and apply qualitative approaches to data collection, analysis and reporting.
 M4 Critically appraise the value of ethical frameworks for research and understand the application of these to a range of research environments.

Within assessment 2, examples of real/published data sets will be used on which students can review and apply the learning engaged through the module. addition, students (in discussion with the Module Team) will select a current research paper within their own field of interest to critically review.

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to analyse data and critique papers effectively, informing their knowledge base and application to research practice.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the student's professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Masters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their developing proficiency in two key elements of understanding and applying research processes: critical review of research; applied analysis and reporting on research data. These assessments will establish a foundation for students who then wish to advance further and develop a research protocol (MDSC702 Advanced Research Methods: Design and Data Analysis).

1.Critical Review c. 2000 words
Students must produce a critical review of a research paper (pre-approved / student's own choice) and will provide an in-depth appraisal critiquing the supporting literature review, research methods, analysis of results and reporting of the findings.

2. Data Analysis Task - Poster Presentation
Students will be required to examine and analyse a set of qualitative and quantitative data, then create and present a poster highlighting the findings from their analysis.

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module. For Assessment 1, students will need to familiarise themselves with critical approaches to review research papers (e.g. GREENHALGH, T. How to read a paper - 5th ed ISBN 9781118801116) apply tools that support critical review (such as CASP https://casp-uk.net/) and required reporting guidelines (https://www.equator-network.org/). For Assessment 2, students will need to engage with, practice and apply analysis techniques identified within the module learning opportunities provided.

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Reviewing research evidence, and preparing research data for presentation and publication are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of authentic assessment.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

MDSC701
Notes
Introduction to Research Methods is a 15 credit module that can be taken as part of a programme of study, or as a stand-alone introduction for students with little or no background in Research Methods. This module is a revised version of the 20 Credit "Research Methods Online" and is suitable for all health care professionals and social scientists.

The staff involved in teaching this module will span the Faculty, allowing expertise to be drawn from the specialist academic areas from the programmes of study in which the module sits. This will allow influence of context and relevance of specialist research methods knowledge.

Overview

Overview
This introductory module provides an opportunity to students to develop understanding of the research process, from the theoretical stances that support empirical enquiry, to the publication of the evidence.

This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Students will need to opt into one of the delivery patterns prior to starting the module.

The module is structured with seven weeks teaching activity using e-lectures and small group work. The staff will deliver the e-lectures in a way that promotes active learning, by using a “sliced” approach where activities (questions, critical reflection) punctuate the presentation. Materials covered within e-lectures are consolidated through small group work, where students will work in dedicated learning sets to address topics for wider discussion amongst the larger group.

The summative assessment will employ the critical skills developed over the course of the module, through the structured critique of a student selected research paper, and the analysis of a provided data set. This assessment strategy will ensure that students have the opportunity to demonstrate key skills within the research process, and provides students with the opportunity to focus on areas of interest specific to their academic/clinical practice.

The module content will be taught by a range of experts from across the Health and Life Science Faculty. Its format has been designed to widen national and international participation, to increase numbers and viability.
Educational Aims
The aims and subsequent learning outcomes have been developed using a knowledge, clinical/research skills, learner development and professional behaviour format, commensurate with the philosophical hallmarks outlined in the University of Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Commensurate with Masters/Level 7 study, this module will:
•Facilitate the development of basic knowledge and core skills in qualitative and quantitative research;
•Enable students to develop a critical awareness of the processes required for successful planning and delivery of research;
•Equip students with appropriate and transferable communication skills for the development of research processes and reporting of analysis.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will facilitate students to develop a critical understanding and ability to appraise the design, development, process and analysis of research within health and social science. The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework hallmarks engaging: Research Connected Teaching; Active Learning, and Authentic Assessment. Further, the curriculum will provide students with the opportunity to develop: Confidence - in their skills and knowledge of research methods; Digital fluency - through engaging digital platforms for academic development and educational activities; and Global Citizenship - through encountering and appreciating international approaches and perspectives on the collection and analysis of data.

The module is aimed at those who have little experience in research and are looking to prepare for a masters level research project. At the end of this module, students will be able to understand and appropriately critique the elements of 'the research journey' from the conception of an idea, through development/approval, execution, analysis and reporting.

The syllabus for this module is aligned with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework and demonstrates active learning and authentic assessment, designed to develop confidence and understanding of research evidence, and how this influences their own area of practice.

The module will have a flexible approach, and will be delivered; online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Delivery will be supported by lectures, audiovisual presentations, quizzes and case-based interactive discussion boards and tutorials.

There are two assessments within this module, aligned to the development of core research skills:
1. Critique of a Research Article: 2,000 words
2. Data Analysis Activity: Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis Exercise: Poster Presentation.

The assessments can be tailored to focus on the student's area of interest and area of speciality.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus for this module is aligned to the hallmarks of the University of Liverpool Curriculum Framework. The syllabus is structured to ensure that current research and thinking supports the development of a critical understanding of research methods; that students are active learners and engage with the material and teaching team to direct their learning and participate in assessments that are contextualised for their professional development.

The syllabus incorporates the following key areas:

-Theoretical underpinnings of research enquiry: Ontology, Epistemology, Paradigms and Research Methods.

-Principles of critical appraisal: Research Design & Methodologies; Evaluation Tools (EQUATOR Network; CASP); Reliability; Validity; Bias; Analysis and Reporting.

-Structured approaches to literature review: Principles of Review; Review Formats (Systematic, Scoping, Narrative); Structuring Reviews (PRISMA; PRISMA-ScR; SWiM; SANRA).

-Introduction to qualitative research and data analysis: Research Problems and Qualitative Methods; Study Design; Sampling; Data Collection Techniques; Introducing approaches to data analysis (Thematic Analysis; Grounded Theory; Integrated Phenomenological Analysis).

-Introduction to quantitative research and data analysis: Research Problems and Quantitative Methods; Study Design; Sampling frameworks; Data Collection Techniques; Understanding Data; Introducing approaches to descriptive and inferential analysis.

-Research ethics: History of Ethics in Health and Social Science Research; Core Principles of Research Ethics; Regulatory Frameworks for Approval.

-Writing for research publication: Principles of Academic Writing; Writing a Research Paper.

The syllabus is actioned through the release of weekly online lectures, addressing the core content and learning objectives of theme for the week.

Lectures: are presented in a "sliced" format - where questions /reflection points are integrated, and students are required to address the activities outlined. For example, during a lecture students may be asked to identify the strengths and limitations of an 'evidence based approach' to practice - pause the lecture whilst they note their thoughts (and findings from internet searches) - and contract their thoughts with those subsequently presented in the lecture.

Group Work: The learning points addressed in the Lectures will form part of the core activity within the online group learning (Learning Sets n=6-8) following the online lecture. Here, students will reflect on identified reading, linked videos and prompted questions relating to the weekly theme. Students will post thoughts, reflections and findings on a discussion board within the VLE, which is supported/moderated daily by the teaching staff. A weekly rotating student chair will be appointed to drive the discussion and report back from the group, to the wider class.

Tutorials: Students are able to access tutorial support in relation to the module content. Equally, learning sets can set up a group tutorial as required/needed to discuss core content.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. The module uses a blend of video lectures, asynchronous discussion boards, and tutorials to progressively build students understanding of a range of research knowledge and practical skills for research.

Sliced Lectures
Topics within the syllabus are introduced with weekly pre-recorded sliced lectures (where questions are asked within the lecture presentation and students are asked to reflect and address points within the presentation). (14 Hours)

Learning Sets
Following the weekly Lecture, the use of tutorials or discussion boards is used to post questions to reflect and engage with. Students will be split into active learning sets (minimum 6, maximum 8) to engage with the discussion question. This activity can take place asynchronously or synchronously according to the demands/opportunities within the learning set (this approach ensures active learning and participation in either an on-line or face to face environment; it also addresses connectedness and personal responsibility for learning). For all students, one member from the learning set (on a rotational basis) will post the findings on a module-wide discussion board, where students can further review, analyse and provide constructive critical comment. (35 Hours)

Supervision
To enable student to structure and focus their learning and structure appropriate assessments, 1-1 supervision is provided. (1.5 hours). Group supervision sessions will complement the above (2.5 hours).

Self-Directed Learning
Students will be required to access directed and supplementary material on a week-by-week basis, aligned to the subject being addressed each week. This information will be presented within the VLE, such as directed/suggested reading material to support the online lecture material and/or group learning activities. The students will also direct their learning to further material pertinent to their particular area of interest (academic/professional) in order to support assessment activities. (97 Hours)

The curriculum for this module is aligned to the hallmarks of the University of Liverpool Curriculum framework:

Research Connected Teaching
The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of basic and clinical sciences with research. The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms.

Authentic Assessment
Within assessment 2, examples of real/published data sets will be used on which students can review and apply the learning engaged through the module. addition, students (in discussion with the Module Team) will select a current research paper within their own field of interest to critically review.

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to analyse data and critique papers effectively, informing their knowledge base and application to research practice.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the student's professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Masters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their developing proficiency in two key elements of understanding and applying research processes: critical review of research; applied analysis and reporting on research data. These assessments will establish a foundation for students who then wish to advance further and develop a research protocol (MDSC702 Advanced Research Methods: Design and Data Analysis).

1.Critical Review c. 2000 words
Students must produce a critical review of a research paper (pre-approved / student's own choice) and will provide an in-depth appraisal critiquing the supporting literature review, research methods, analysis of results and reporting of the findings.

2. Data Analysis Task - Poster Presentation
Students will be required to examine and analyse a set of qualitative and quantitative data, then create and present a poster highlighting the findings from their analysis.

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module. For Assessment 1, students will need to familiarise themselves with critical approaches to review research papers (e.g. GREENHALGH, T. How to read a paper - 5th ed ISBN 9781118801116) apply tools that support critical review (such as CASP https://casp-uk.net/) and required reporting guidelines (https://www.equator-network.org/). For Assessment 2, students will need to engage with, practice and apply analysis techniques identified within the module learning opportunities provided.

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Reviewing research evidence, and preparing research data for presentation and publication are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of authentic assessment.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

MDSC701
Notes
Introduction to Research Methods is a 15 credit module that can be taken as part of a programme of study, or as a stand-alone introduction for students with little or no background in Research Methods. This module is a revised version of the 20 Credit "Research Methods Online" and is suitable for all health care professionals and social scientists.

The staff involved in teaching this module will span the Faculty, allowing expertise to be drawn from the specialist academic areas from the programmes of study in which the module sits. This will allow influence of context and relevance of specialist research methods knowledge.

Overview

Overview
This introductory module provides an opportunity to students to develop understanding of the research process, from the theoretical stances that support empirical enquiry, to the publication of the evidence.

This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Students will need to opt into one of the delivery patterns prior to starting the module.

The module is structured with seven weeks teaching activity using e-lectures and small group work. The staff will deliver the e-lectures in a way that promotes active learning, by using a “sliced” approach where activities (questions, critical reflection) punctuate the presentation. Materials covered within e-lectures are consolidated through small group work, where students will work in dedicated learning sets to address topics for wider discussion amongst the larger group.

The summative assessment will employ the critical skills developed over the course of the module, through the structured critique of a student selected research paper, and the analysis of a provided data set. This assessment strategy will ensure that students have the opportunity to demonstrate key skills within the research process, and provides students with the opportunity to focus on areas of interest specific to their academic/clinical practice.

The module content will be taught by a range of experts from across the Health and Life Science Faculty. Its format has been designed to widen national and international participation, to increase numbers and viability.
Educational Aims
The aims and subsequent learning outcomes have been developed using a knowledge, clinical/research skills, learner development and professional behaviour format, commensurate with the philosophical hallmarks outlined in the University of Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Commensurate with Masters/Level 7 study, this module will:
•Facilitate the development of basic knowledge and core skills in qualitative and quantitative research;
•Enable students to develop a critical awareness of the processes required for successful planning and delivery of research;
•Equip students with appropriate and transferable communication skills for the development of research processes and reporting of analysis.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will facilitate students to develop a critical understanding and ability to appraise the design, development, process and analysis of research within health and social science. The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework hallmarks engaging: Research Connected Teaching; Active Learning, and Authentic Assessment. Further, the curriculum will provide students with the opportunity to develop: Confidence - in their skills and knowledge of research methods; Digital fluency - through engaging digital platforms for academic development and educational activities; and Global Citizenship - through encountering and appreciating international approaches and perspectives on the collection and analysis of data.

The module is aimed at those who have little experience in research and are looking to prepare for a masters level research project. At the end of this module, students will be able to understand and appropriately critique the elements of 'the research journey' from the conception of an idea, through development/approval, execution, analysis and reporting.

The syllabus for this module is aligned with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework and demonstrates active learning and authentic assessment, designed to develop confidence and understanding of research evidence, and how this influences their own area of practice.

The module will have a flexible approach, and will be delivered; online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Delivery will be supported by lectures, audiovisual presentations, quizzes and case-based interactive discussion boards and tutorials.

There are two assessments within this module, aligned to the development of core research skills:
1. Critique of a Research Article: 2,000 words
2. Data Analysis Activity: Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis Exercise: Poster Presentation.

The assessments can be tailored to focus on the student's area of interest and area of speciality.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus for this module is aligned to the hallmarks of the University of Liverpool Curriculum Framework. The syllabus is structured to ensure that current research and thinking supports the development of a critical understanding of research methods; that students are active learners and engage with the material and teaching team to direct their learning and participate in assessments that are contextualised for their professional development.

The syllabus incorporates the following key areas:

-Theoretical underpinnings of research enquiry: Ontology, Epistemology, Paradigms and Research Methods.

-Principles of critical appraisal: Research Design & Methodologies; Evaluation Tools (EQUATOR Network; CASP); Reliability; Validity; Bias; Analysis and Reporting.

-Structured approaches to literature review: Principles of Review; Review Formats (Systematic, Scoping, Narrative); Structuring Reviews (PRISMA; PRISMA-ScR; SWiM; SANRA).

-Introduction to qualitative research and data analysis: Research Problems and Qualitative Methods; Study Design; Sampling; Data Collection Techniques; Introducing approaches to data analysis (Thematic Analysis; Grounded Theory; Integrated Phenomenological Analysis).

-Introduction to quantitative research and data analysis: Research Problems and Quantitative Methods; Study Design; Sampling frameworks; Data Collection Techniques; Understanding Data; Introducing approaches to descriptive and inferential analysis.

-Research ethics: History of Ethics in Health and Social Science Research; Core Principles of Research Ethics; Regulatory Frameworks for Approval.

-Writing for research publication: Principles of Academic Writing; Writing a Research Paper.

The syllabus is actioned through the release of weekly online lectures, addressing the core content and learning objectives of theme for the week.

Lectures: are presented in a "sliced" format - where questions /reflection points are integrated, and students are required to address the activities outlined. For example, during a lecture students may be asked to identify the strengths and limitations of an 'evidence based approach' to practice - pause the lecture whilst they note their thoughts (and findings from internet searches) - and contract their thoughts with those subsequently presented in the lecture.

Group Work: The learning points addressed in the Lectures will form part of the core activity within the online group learning (Learning Sets n=6-8) following the online lecture. Here, students will reflect on identified reading, linked videos and prompted questions relating to the weekly theme. Students will post thoughts, reflections and findings on a discussion board within the VLE, which is supported/moderated daily by the teaching staff. A weekly rotating student chair will be appointed to drive the discussion and report back from the group, to the wider class.

Tutorials: Students are able to access tutorial support in relation to the module content. Equally, learning sets can set up a group tutorial as required/needed to discuss core content.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. The module uses a blend of video lectures, asynchronous discussion boards, and tutorials to progressively build students understanding of a range of research knowledge and practical skills for research.

Sliced Lectures
Topics within the syllabus are introduced with weekly pre-recorded sliced lectures (where questions are asked within the lecture presentation and students are asked to reflect and address points within the presentation). (14 Hours)

Learning Sets
Following the weekly Lecture, the use of tutorials or discussion boards is used to post questions to reflect and engage with. Students will be split into active learning sets (minimum 6, maximum 8) to engage with the discussion question. This activity can take place asynchronously or synchronously according to the demands/opportunities within the learning set (this approach ensures active learning and participation in either an on-line or face to face environment; it also addresses connectedness and personal responsibility for learning). For all students, one member from the learning set (on a rotational basis) will post the findings on a module-wide discussion board, where students can further review, analyse and provide constructive critical comment. (35 Hours)

Supervision
To enable student to structure and focus their learning and structure appropriate assessments, 1-1 supervision is provided. (1.5 hours). Group supervision sessions will complement the above (2.5 hours).

Self-Directed Learning
Students will be required to access directed and supplementary material on a week-by-week basis, aligned to the subject being addressed each week. This information will be presented within the VLE, such as directed/suggested reading material to support the online lecture material and/or group learning activities. The students will also direct their learning to further material pertinent to their particular area of interest (academic/professional) in order to support assessment activities. (97 Hours)

The curriculum for this module is aligned to the hallmarks of the University of Liverpool Curriculum framework:

Research Connected Teaching
The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of basic and clinical sciences with research. The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms.

Authentic Assessment
Within assessment 2, examples of real/published data sets will be used on which students can review and apply the learning engaged through the module. addition, students (in discussion with the Module Team) will select a current research paper within their own field of interest to critically review.

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to analyse data and critique papers effectively, informing their knowledge base and application to research practice.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the student's professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Masters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their developing proficiency in two key elements of understanding and applying research processes: critical review of research; applied analysis and reporting on research data. These assessments will establish a foundation for students who then wish to advance further and develop a research protocol (MDSC702 Advanced Research Methods: Design and Data Analysis).

1.Critical Review c. 2000 words
Students must produce a critical review of a research paper (pre-approved / student's own choice) and will provide an in-depth appraisal critiquing the supporting literature review, research methods, analysis of results and reporting of the findings.

2. Data Analysis Task - Poster Presentation
Students will be required to examine and analyse a set of qualitative and quantitative data, then create and present a poster highlighting the findings from their analysis.

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module. For Assessment 1, students will need to familiarise themselves with critical approaches to review research papers (e.g. GREENHALGH, T. How to read a paper - 5th ed ISBN 9781118801116) apply tools that support critical review (such as CASP https://casp-uk.net/) and required reporting guidelines (https://www.equator-network.org/). For Assessment 2, students will need to engage with, practice and apply analysis techniques identified within the module learning opportunities provided.

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Reviewing research evidence, and preparing research data for presentation and publication are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of authentic assessment.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 To articulate and critically appraise theory underpinning a range of qualitative and quantitative approaches to research enquiry.
 M2 To critically appraise and apply quantitative approaches to data collection, analysis and reporting.
 M3 To critically appraise and apply qualitative approaches to data collection, analysis and reporting.
 M4 Critically appraise the value of ethical frameworks for research and understand the application of these to a range of research environments.

Students must produce a critical review of a research paper (pre-approved / student's own choice) and will provide an in-depth appraisal critiquing the supporting literature review, research methods, analysis of results and reporting of the findings.

2. Data Analysis Task - Poster Presentation
Students will be required to examine and analyse a set of qualitative and quantitative data, then create and present a poster highlighting the findings from their analysis.

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module. For Assessment 1, students will need to familiarise themselves with critical approaches to review research papers (e.g. GREENHALGH, T. How to read a paper - 5th ed ISBN 9781118801116) apply tools that support critical review (such as CASP https://casp-uk.net/) and required reporting guidelines (https://www.equator-network.org/). For Assessment 2, students will need to engage with, practice and apply analysis techniques identified within the module learning opportunities provided.

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Reviewing research evidence, and preparing research data for presentation and publication are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of authentic assessment.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

MDSC701
Notes
Introduction to Research Methods is a 15 credit module that can be taken as part of a programme of study, or as a stand-alone introduction for students with little or no background in Research Methods. This module is a revised version of the 20 Credit "Research Methods Online" and is suitable for all health care professionals and social scientists.

The staff involved in teaching this module will span the Faculty, allowing expertise to be drawn from the specialist academic areas from the programmes of study in which the module sits. This will allow influence of context and relevance of specialist research methods knowledge.

Overview

Overview
This introductory module provides an opportunity to students to develop understanding of the research process, from the theoretical stances that support empirical enquiry, to the publication of the evidence.

This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Students will need to opt into one of the delivery patterns prior to starting the module.

The module is structured with seven weeks teaching activity using e-lectures and small group work. The staff will deliver the e-lectures in a way that promotes active learning, by using a “sliced” approach where activities (questions, critical reflection) punctuate the presentation. Materials covered within e-lectures are consolidated through small group work, where students will work in dedicated learning sets to address topics for wider discussion amongst the larger group.

The summative assessment will employ the critical skills developed over the course of the module, through the structured critique of a student selected research paper, and the analysis of a provided data set. This assessment strategy will ensure that students have the opportunity to demonstrate key skills within the research process, and provides students with the opportunity to focus on areas of interest specific to their academic/clinical practice.

The module content will be taught by a range of experts from across the Health and Life Science Faculty. Its format has been designed to widen national and international participation, to increase numbers and viability.
Educational Aims
The aims and subsequent learning outcomes have been developed using a knowledge, clinical/research skills, learner development and professional behaviour format, commensurate with the philosophical hallmarks outlined in the University of Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Commensurate with Masters/Level 7 study, this module will:
•Facilitate the development of basic knowledge and core skills in qualitative and quantitative research;
•Enable students to develop a critical awareness of the processes required for successful planning and delivery of research;
•Equip students with appropriate and transferable communication skills for the development of research processes and reporting of analysis.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will facilitate students to develop a critical understanding and ability to appraise the design, development, process and analysis of research within health and social science. The syllabus for this module is aligned to the Liverpool Curriculum Framework hallmarks engaging: Research Connected Teaching; Active Learning, and Authentic Assessment. Further, the curriculum will provide students with the opportunity to develop: Confidence - in their skills and knowledge of research methods; Digital fluency - through engaging digital platforms for academic development and educational activities; and Global Citizenship - through encountering and appreciating international approaches and perspectives on the collection and analysis of data.

The module is aimed at those who have little experience in research and are looking to prepare for a masters level research project. At the end of this module, students will be able to understand and appropriately critique the elements of 'the research journey' from the conception of an idea, through development/approval, execution, analysis and reporting.

The syllabus for this module is aligned with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework and demonstrates active learning and authentic assessment, designed to develop confidence and understanding of research evidence, and how this influences their own area of practice.

The module will have a flexible approach, and will be delivered; online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. Delivery will be supported by lectures, audiovisual presentations, quizzes and case-based interactive discussion boards and tutorials.

There are two assessments within this module, aligned to the development of core research skills:
1. Critique of a Research Article: 2,000 words
2. Data Analysis Activity: Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis Exercise: Poster Presentation.

The assessments can be tailored to focus on the student's area of interest and area of speciality.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus for this module is aligned to the hallmarks of the University of Liverpool Curriculum Framework. The syllabus is structured to ensure that current research and thinking supports the development of a critical understanding of research methods; that students are active learners and engage with the material and teaching team to direct their learning and participate in assessments that are contextualised for their professional development.

The syllabus incorporates the following key areas:

-Theoretical underpinnings of research enquiry: Ontology, Epistemology, Paradigms and Research Methods.

-Principles of critical appraisal: Research Design & Methodologies; Evaluation Tools (EQUATOR Network; CASP); Reliability; Validity; Bias; Analysis and Reporting.

-Structured approaches to literature review: Principles of Review; Review Formats (Systematic, Scoping, Narrative); Structuring Reviews (PRISMA; PRISMA-ScR; SWiM; SANRA).

-Introduction to qualitative research and data analysis: Research Problems and Qualitative Methods; Study Design; Sampling; Data Collection Techniques; Introducing approaches to data analysis (Thematic Analysis; Grounded Theory; Integrated Phenomenological Analysis).

-Introduction to quantitative research and data analysis: Research Problems and Quantitative Methods; Study Design; Sampling frameworks; Data Collection Techniques; Understanding Data; Introducing approaches to descriptive and inferential analysis.

-Research ethics: History of Ethics in Health and Social Science Research; Core Principles of Research Ethics; Regulatory Frameworks for Approval.

-Writing for research publication: Principles of Academic Writing; Writing a Research Paper.

The syllabus is actioned through the release of weekly online lectures, addressing the core content and learning objectives of theme for the week.

Lectures: are presented in a "sliced" format - where questions /reflection points are integrated, and students are required to address the activities outlined. For example, during a lecture students may be asked to identify the strengths and limitations of an 'evidence based approach' to practice - pause the lecture whilst they note their thoughts (and findings from internet searches) - and contract their thoughts with those subsequently presented in the lecture.

Group Work: The learning points addressed in the Lectures will form part of the core activity within the online group learning (Learning Sets n=6-8) following the online lecture. Here, students will reflect on identified reading, linked videos and prompted questions relating to the weekly theme. Students will post thoughts, reflections and findings on a discussion board within the VLE, which is supported/moderated daily by the teaching staff. A weekly rotating student chair will be appointed to drive the discussion and report back from the group, to the wider class.

Tutorials: Students are able to access tutorial support in relation to the module content. Equally, learning sets can set up a group tutorial as required/needed to discuss core content.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will have a flexible delivery to allow for maximum student engagement across programmes. It will be delivered online, on-campus, or a combination of the two across the semester. The module uses a blend of video lectures, asynchronous discussion boards, and tutorials to progressively build students understanding of a range of research knowledge and practical skills for research.

Sliced Lectures
Topics within the syllabus are introduced with weekly pre-recorded sliced lectures (where questions are asked within the lecture presentation and students are asked to reflect and address points within the presentation). (14 Hours)

Learning Sets
Following the weekly Lecture, the use of tutorials or discussion boards is used to post questions to reflect and engage with. Students will be split into active learning sets (minimum 6, maximum 8) to engage with the discussion question. This activity can take place asynchronously or synchronously according to the demands/opportunities within the learning set (this approach ensures active learning and participation in either an on-line or face to face environment; it also addresses connectedness and personal responsibility for learning). For all students, one member from the learning set (on a rotational basis) will post the findings on a module-wide discussion board, where students can further review, analyse and provide constructive critical comment. (35 Hours)

Supervision
To enable student to structure and focus their learning and structure appropriate assessments, 1-1 supervision is provided. (1.5 hours). Group supervision sessions will complement the above (2.5 hours).

Self-Directed Learning
Students will be required to access directed and supplementary material on a week-by-week basis, aligned to the subject being addressed each week. This information will be presented within the VLE, such as directed/suggested reading material to support the online lecture material and/or group learning activities. The students will also direct their learning to further material pertinent to their particular area of interest (academic/professional) in order to support assessment activities. (97 Hours)

The curriculum for this module is aligned to the hallmarks of the University of Liverpool Curriculum framework:

Research Connected Teaching
The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of basic and clinical sciences with research. The module will provide students with the highest quality active learning experience, through instruction and support of academic staff from across the Faculty. This will ensure teaching is informed by research and best practice evidence, integrating approaches and examples from research practice to promote knowledge and skills development.

Active Learning
The teaching delivery is based on the research support model use for postgraduate research degrees, creating active learning and supporting confidence. The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process, facilitated through the practical experience of reviewing and making sense of data in both qualitative and qualitative forms.

Authentic Assessment
Within assessment 2, examples of real/published data sets will be used on which students can review and apply the learning engaged through the module. addition, students (in discussion with the Module Team) will select a current research paper within their own field of interest to critically review.

Confidence
The teaching syllabus designed to equip students with confidence in the knowledge and skills required to analyse data and critique papers effectively, informing their knowledge base and application to research practice.

Digital Fluency
The module uses digital platform for communication with the students learning sets, and digital platforms to accumulate and examine the current evidence base.

Global Citizenship
Content will be taught by teaching faculty drawn from existing national and international collaborations, who will promote a global perspective on their research within their area.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The Assessment Strategy has been guided by the Curriculum 2021 Framework, Attributes, and Hallmarks. In particular, the module has been designed to include (authentic) assessment that is meaningful for the student's professional/future professional role, and for further progress in Masters/Level 7 studies (preparing for Masters/Level 7 Dissertation/Research).

The Assessments will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their developing proficiency in two key elements of understanding and applying research processes: critical review of research; applied analysis and reporting on research data. These assessments will establish a foundation for students who then wish to advance further and develop a research protocol (MDSC702 Advanced Research Methods: Design and Data Analysis).

1.Critical Review c. 2000 words
Students must produce a critical review of a research paper (pre-approved / student's own choice) and will provide an in-depth appraisal critiquing the supporting literature review, research methods, analysis of results and reporting of the findings.

2. Data Analysis Task - Poster Presentation
Students will be required to examine and analyse a set of qualitative and quantitative data, then create and present a poster highlighting the findings from their analysis.

To successfully complete these assessments, students will be required to engage with the Teaching and Learning activities outlined within the module. For Assessment 1, students will need to familiarise themselves with critical approaches to review research papers (e.g. GREENHALGH, T. How to read a paper - 5th ed ISBN 9781118801116) apply tools that support critical review (such as CASP https://casp-uk.net/) and required reporting guidelines (https://www.equator-network.org/). For Assessment 2, students will need to engage with, practice and apply analysis techniques identified within the module learning opportunities provided.

Students who fail the review and/or report will be assessed through a repeated attempt and improving the previously submitted assignment.

Reviewing research evidence, and preparing research data for presentation and publication are important skills for current and future practice, and are part of authentic assessment.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
